text: Beautifully preserved 19th century architecture with a rich cultural heritage that spans over 160 years. Note that Masjid Al-Abrar is now located in a bustling area, with nearby establishments including bars and restaurants serving alcohol. Despite this, the mosque remains a tranquil escape from the surrounding activity

Near amoy street, if your bus stop around chinatown, you can go the direction through ann siang hill park, and go through  the alley, but perhaps it is not comfortable if you bring stroller or luggage. The place is so tidy and convenient, the air con works so well and the water very refreshing to take wudhu

Completed my work and rushed to get my Subur Prayers at 635am. Four pairs of shoes was seen at entrance and I could hear people talking inside. But all 3 doors were locked from inside. Tried opening and knocking but nobody opened. Mosque management should look into this immediately.
I understand, the mosque closes at Sunrise and reopens for Zohor prayers, but 635am ?
Quaint Masjid in the centre of busy office locality, Jummah quthbah in Tamil, two jamaats for Friday Namaaz

Alhamdullilah. It is a gem to find a masjid in the middle of street within the CBD that is full of worldly bustle. The interior is so peaceful and allows one to unwind from his/her worries. It is run primarily by the Tamil-Muslim community so if you aren’t used to a different style of prayers, you may want to consider someplace else (quite speedy and no provision for Ruku’).

For drivers, as many before me have mentioned, it can be quite difficult as you’d imagine in the CBD. If streetside parking isn’t available, there’s Frasers Tower along Telok Ayer St.
